constructs.name: perceived_engineering_competence
constructs.description: Subjective feeling of being a competent engineer - the sense of mastery, capability, and professional self-efficacy

constructs.name: deep_technical_learning
constructs.description: Sustained engagement with complex technical topics like programming concepts, algorithms, cryptography, or systems design

constructs.name: comparative_learning
constructs.description: Searches comparing or contrasting concepts, indicating active synthesis and deeper understanding

constructs.name: problem_solving_activity
constructs.description: Active debugging, troubleshooting, and fixing technical issues - the practical application of engineering skills

constructs.name: technical_depth_engagement
constructs.description: Engagement with advanced, authoritative technical sources indicating serious study

constructs.name: browsing_topic
constructs.description: The topical category of each browsing event - used to compute attention fragmentation via entropy

constructs.name: cognitive_capacity
constructs.description: Underlying mental energy and capacity for focused intellectual work - not directly observed but inferred

constructs.name: intellectual_curiosity_exploration
constructs.description: Exploratory learning driven by curiosity rather than immediate work needs

constructs.name: mental_health_seeking
constructs.description: Searches related to mental health, mood enhancement substances, depression - indicates potential struggles affecting engineering capacity

constructs.name: late_night_activity
constructs.description: Browsing activity during late night hours - proxy for sleep disruption or irregular schedule affecting next-day cognition

constructs.name: leisure_browsing
constructs.description: Non-technical leisure activities - can indicate both healthy recovery and potential avoidance/distraction

constructs.name: health_optimization_interest
constructs.description: Interest in health tracking, biohacking, and self-optimization - indicates proactive self-management orientation

constructs.name: is_weekend
constructs.description: Whether the day is Saturday or Sunday - affects available time and type of engagement

constructs.name: total_browsing_volume
constructs.description: Overall daily activity level - baseline engagement with digital world

constructs.name: morning_technical_start
constructs.description: Whether technical work began in the morning - indicates disciplined routine enabling deep work

constructs.name: technology_evaluation
constructs.description: Exploring and comparing tools, languages, frameworks - indicates growth mindset and staying current

constructs.name: hardware_tooling_interest
constructs.description: Interest in engineering hardware and tooling setup - indicates investment in craft

edges.description: Higher cognitive capacity enables sustained engagement with complex technical topics
Lower cognitive capacity leads to higher entropy in browsing topics (more scattered)
Cognitive resources are needed for effective debugging and troubleshooting
Mental health struggles (indicated by substance/therapy seeking) deplete cognitive capacity the following day
Late night browsing disrupts sleep, reducing next-day cognitive capacity
Proactive health management leads to improved cognitive capacity over time
Successfully engaging with complex technical material directly builds sense of competence
Actively comparing and contrasting concepts indicates synthesis and reinforces competence feeling
Successfully debugging and fixing issues demonstrates practical engineering capability
Engaging with serious technical sources signals to self that one is doing real engineering work
Higher topic entropy (fragmentation) undermines sense of competence; focused browsing supports it
Curiosity-driven learning reinforces identity as thoughtful, engaged engineer
Evaluating and comparing technologies maintains sense of relevance and growth
Deep engagement with technical topics leads to comparative queries as understanding deepens
Reading authoritative sources prompts comparison of approaches and concepts
Curiosity provides motivation for sustained technical engagement
Same-day leisure browsing competes for time with deep technical work (negative)
Leisure and recovery activities restore cognitive capacity for the next day
Weekends naturally have more leisure browsing
Weekends may enable more personal technical learning or reduce work-related learning
Higher overall activity creates more opportunity for deep technical engagement
Starting technical work in the morning enables more accumulated deep work
Morning starts correlate with more focused (lower entropy) browsing patterns
Feeling competent motivates continued technical learning - virtuous cycle
Competence feeling frees mental space for curious exploration
Investing in engineering craft and tools reinforces professional identity
Debugging problems drives consultation of authoritative documentation
Mental health struggles manifest as more scattered (higher entropy) browsing same day
Higher topic entropy (fragmentation) inhibits ability to engage deeply (negative)
Evaluating new technologies sparks broader intellectual curiosity
Low cognitive capacity may drive escape into leisure browsing as avoidance
More overall browsing creates more opportunity for leisure content
Mental energy enables exploration of unfamiliar technical territory
Feeling competent gives confidence to explore and evaluate new technologies
